TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few short points about the shabby treatment that has been meted out this year to local government. I think it is very important that when the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance is presented in October, the Government and this Parliament give the report detailed and sensitive consideration. With the announcement of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that there will not be any referendums before 1987, the constitutional recognition of local government has been placed on a back-burner, despite the fact that it was recommended by the Australian Constitutional Convention. State governments will still be able to dismiss local councils for a variety of political reasons totally unrelated to standards of administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this week a deal was made between right wing Labor and Liberal aldermen to de- stabilise the Sydney City Council and prevent reforms from being carried out in that city. Last May that same right wing Labor and Liberal partnership ganged up in this Parliament to make it possible for personal income tax sharing moneys to be snatched from local government at the last moment. Councils in New South Wales were nearly half way into their financial year. They had to readjust their budgets, cut services, and let opportunities go because of the rate-pegging regime that had been introduced by the Wran Government. The problem would not have been so bad if either the Government or the Opposition had stuck to the promise of 2 per cent of personal income tax for local government. For instance, the shire of Warracknabeal wrote to me saying:
Council cannot believe that the Liberal and National Party voted with Labor in slicing back the promised 2% and has written to the leaders of both parties requesting an explanation.

At this stage I do not believe that the Council has received an explanation. Mr Howard said at the time of the mini-Budget that local government had been treated gently. I do not believe this to be the case. The newly-appointed shadow Minister, Mr Beale, has said that local government should not get anything. No wonder Opposition senators lined up to make sure the councils would not get the money they were promised. The Australian Democrats alone stood up for local government in this situation.

I hope that the report of the Self Inquiry into Local Government Finance will be read without prejudice or political opportunism. I hope that honourable senators will take the opportunity to consult the transcript of evidence on some of the key points and take heed of the views of those who serve this level of government which is closest to the people. The whole exercise of taking evidence, collecting factual material and analysing data will have been pointless if the Government and the Parliament take a knee-jerk reaction or sweep the report under the table. The report is due out between now and the time the Parliament returns. I believe that we should take careful note of it. Local government should be our partner in serving Australians everywhere. Let us recognise it as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank honourable senators for their contributions, particularly those who made short contributions, to the adjournment debate. I will comment briefly. Senator Kilgariff spoke early. Senator Gareth Evans has assured me that he will examine Senator Kilgariff's point about Kakadu National Park. I guess the honourable senator can expect a response from him in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen made a long speech about Amnesty International, particularly about Irian Jaya and the relationship of the Australian Government with Indonesia. I will refer the contents of Senator Missen's speech to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) with a request that he see the Amnesty group. With regard to the questions on notice to which Senator Missen referred, I will see whether an early answer can be obtained. Senator Missen devoted some time to discussing the position of five refugees held on a Torres Strait island and the comments of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) about that issue. I will not accede to the request that the Cabinet's minutes be made available. I think there is some serious disagreement between the Government and Senator Missen about the circumstances and the importance, both in international relations terms and in human terms, of this issue. That is a matter which I will ask the Foreign Minister to address.

Senator Mason called again for a judicial inquiry into the Chamberlain case. I do not know whether the Commonwealth really has a function in respect of that matter, but I will refer his request to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). Senator Vanstone asked that Australia Post give recognition to the wine industry. I totally agree with her point about the importance of the wine industry and the assistance and recognition which it should be given. I do not know that the symbolism of a postage stamp will take the wine industry very far, but I will certainly refer the honourable senator's request to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). In the case of Senator Crichton-Browne's comments, I will refer them to Mr Malcolm Fraser.

Senator Vigor made a few comments about local government. I think we would be in fundamental disagreement with him about the generosity with which local government is treated. Indeed, I suppose we would be in fundamental disagreement with him about the role of rational and reasonable government in this country on this issue. I understand the honourable senator's concern for local government. It must be regarded as admirable. But whether the Commonwealth should do more for it I very much doubt.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Gaslight Estate, Evatt, Australian Captial Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, 10 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: In respect of the development of the Gaslight Estate at Evatt, using fast tracking construction:
(a) what was the total cost of developing each block of land on which a Government house has been erected;
(b) what was the total cost of erecting each Government house in the first stage of this development; and
(c) how do these costs compare with similar developments on Government serviced land using conventional construction methods.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following response has been provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In arriving at the payment for the lease of the estate an allowance of $540 000 was made to cover the cost of servicing the 30 Government house sites (i.e. $18 000 per block). Costs were not determined for individual blocks.
(b) The cost charged for the 30 Government houses provided in the Estate was $1 266 000. This is an average cost of $42 200.

(c) The allowance made for the cost of land servicing was about the same as for a National Capital Development Commission undertaking. Based on average cost per square metre the cost charged for the Government housing was again about the same as for National Captial Development Commission constructed houses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of supporting parents' benefits paid in 1983-84.
(2) What proportion of the cost in (1) above can be attributed to payments to:
(a) unmarried parents;
(b) widows not eligible for the widow's pension;
(c) separated husbands or wives;
(d) persons whose spouse has been imprisoned for 14 days or more; or
(e) persons who cannot live with their spouse because of illness or infirmity.
(3) What proportion of the cost in (1) above can be attributed to fathers defaulting on their maintenance payments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Expenditure on sub-groups of supporting parent beneficiaries is not separately identified. However, of the number of supporting parent beneficiaries current at 30 June 1984:
(a) 28.1 per cent were unmarried parents;
(b) a negligible percentage were widows not eligible for widow's pension;
(c) 57.0 per cent were separated husbands or wives (a further 12.3 per cent were separated de facto husbands or wives);
(d) 0.2 per cent had a spouse who had been imprisoned for 14 days or more;
(e) a negligible percentage were persons unable to live with their spouse because of illness or infirmity.
(3) No information is available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Education of Children of Members of the Defence Force

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What provision is made by the defence forces to assist families in regard to the education of their children.
(2) How does the Department of Defence minimise the effect of disrupted schooling among children of defence personnel.
(3) Does the Department have a policy to avoid mid-year transfers.
(4) Does the Department liaise with state education departments to ensure families have up to date information about schooling in different states.
(5) Does the Department offer any tutoring schemes to assist those children whose education suffers as a result of transfers and different standards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Families may be assisted, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, by the payment of a non-taxable Education Allowance.

This is payable to assist in defraying costs incurred when, on long term posting within Australia, a member wishes to leave his or her child in the present school or education system, in order to prevent serious interference to the child's secondary education.

The Allowance is also payable for limited periods when a member places a child in a new locality in advance of his or her posting, to avoid subsequent serious interference; and may be payable in other circumstances such as when difficulties in arranging secondary education for handicapped children arise on posting.

(2) With the intention of minimising disruption and inconvenience to families where a mid-year move becomes necessary, in addition to considering the needs of the Service, the posting authorities consider such family factors as the number of children and their ages, and whether the member's wife is working.

Provision exists for a member to move unaccompanied to his or her new location until the end of the school year, or school term, when he or she can then return to uplift his or her family to the new posting location.

(3) Although there is no set policy which directs posting authorities to avoid mid-year postings, planning gives high priority, to the need to reduce as far as possible the number of postings involving mid-year movement of personnel. The vast majority of postings occur in December/January of each year with only the absolute minimum occurring mid-year. Most of the necessary mid-year postings are for personnel attending training courses, both overseas and in Australia. Other mid-year postings are occasioned by the requirement to replace personnel who resign or retire from the Defence Force or to fill newly established positions.

(4) On a continuing basis, the Department seeks information from Education Departments at both headquarters and regional level. This information is provided to unit or establishment education officers who provide an advisory service to personnel undergoing interstate posting.
(5) No such schemes exist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August (Hansard, page 290) Senator Harradine asked me a question without notice about the establishment of a company called IVF Australia Ltd. I was unable to answer part of the question and undertook to seek a reply to that part as soon as I could. I am now able to give the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: A company by the name IVF Australia Pty Ltd was incorporated in Victoria on 12 June 1985.

Companies are no longer required to state their objectives in their memorandum of association. However, I am advised that, in a letter seeking reservation of the company name prior to incorporation, the nature of business to be conducted by the company was stated to be the provision of services of in vitro fertilisation.

The question of the commercial exploitation of reproductive technology is one that the Government will be considering in formulating its response to the Family Law Council Report referred to in the second part of the Hon. Senator's question.
For the information of Hon. Senators, the Family Law Council noted that:

`The Community needs to give careful consideration to the appropriateness of permitting the Commercial exploitation of reproductive technology-and, if the latter is to be permitted, to its regulation.'
It also recommended (at paragraph 6.11.1) that the commercial exploitation of reproductive technology be considered by the proposed National Council on Reproductive Technology.
